column4: Which filesystem and what mount point should my boot partition have when configuring the partitions manually?
If you need a separate boot partition, ext2 is good, since you won't be writing to it much, and 64 MB is plenty
I don't know if I need it, I just followed some people their instruction, is it better to have a seperate boot partition?
Thought unless you have a specific need for a separate boot partition (BIOS issues, multiple Linuxs, etc), don't worry with it.
so I can leave that behind and just get a swap, root and home?
I don't see why not.
Like I said, unless you have a specific need for it, I wouldn't worry with it.
ok, thanks, last question: what mount point should I set for my windows partition?
Are you setting up Ubuntu with the normal desktop graphical installer or something like the alternate install?
ubuntu 10.04 live Cd, installing from the GUI
I wouldn't worry with specifying your windows mount point either. udev will detect it and automatically mount it based on label or UUID to a folder in /media
Or even if it doesn't mount it automatically, it will mount it when you click on it
Are you just trying to set up a separate home partition?
yes, I am

Then you just need to worry about root, swap and home. Make root 5-10gb, depending on how many apps you like to install, put at least as much as your ram for swap (assuming you want to have hibernate), and share the rest as you wish between /home and Windows.
taht was my plan ^^
If you have enough ram, and don't care about hibernate, you could even leave swap out completely or make it smaller so you have more storage space. It all depends on how you use your computer.
ok, thanks, I'll let you know if I managed or not :)
so my NTFS (windows partition) its mount point is freely to choose?
For Windows, just specifiy "don't use this partition" (or whatever the text for that option is... I forget the specifics)
udev will automatically handle it in /media
